2.2 Technical Specifications Required specifications (TOR Section 3.1) for a new borehole are
listed below:
1) Final depth of the cased borehole will be at least 70m below ground
level
2) All required supplies -casings, components, materials, and additional
supplies- shall be new and first grade
3) The well casing shall extend above the ground about 60cm. The top
end must have a sealed cap or wellhead box to prevent water
ingress. For a steel casing, the exposed top section must be painted
or coated to prevent corrosion
4) Angle of inclination from vertical will not to exceed 2.5 degrees at
any point in the borehole
5)
Casing must be completely round, with no ellipticity; the inner
surface of casing must be smooth with no irregularities such as welds
or couplings, which would reduce the inner diameter
6) The casing must be well cemented into the ground, from the bottom
up
7) Steel casing with water-tight joints will be installed for the entire
length of the borehole
8) Inner diameter of the casing should be between 12.7 and 17.8 cm (5
and 7 inches) with a minimum casing wall thickness of 0.62 cm (0.244
inches).
9) A water-tight cement or steel plug should be completely cemented
to the bottom of the borehole.
10)
The outer wall of casing should be completely cemented to the rock
along the entire length of the borehole; cementation must ensure
high-quality contact between the casing and the rock walls
11)

the drilling starts

1. Summary of the project
The 3 Component Auxiliary Seismic Station AS097 at Babate, Senegal (hereinafter referred to
as “the Station”) is part of the International Monitoring System (IMS) of the Preparatory
Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization (hereinafter
referred to as “the Commission”). More information can be found under www.ctbto.org
The name, code and coordinates for the Station are Babate, BBTS, 14.66132° N, 16.53323° W.
The Station is at the site located approximately 75 km from the city of Mbour, Senegal. The
station is certified in 2007, to install the sensor inside the borehole, a 70m deep borehole was
drilled in 2004; obstruction, verticality and leaking tests have been performed but later it’s been
found that borehole had about 50m of water inside the casing. It was decided to drill another
borehole which was drilled in 2006. After the drilling, a slight leaking was observed, but sensor
was installed inside the borehole. Over the years, water and mud filled up the borehole and
resulted corrosion on the casing. In 2023 the damaged sensor was pulled up and water was
cleaned, however some water leakage was observed after the cleaning as well. Summary of the
report from the contractor is given in Section 7 in these TOR.
The Commission considers rehabilitating the existing borehole (LOT 1) or drilling a new
borehole (LOT 2) and seeking a company specialized in these types of works. The Contractor
can provide proposals on one or both lots.
LOT 1: Rehabilitating the existing borehole include (Section 2);
- Cleaning the borehole
- Cleaning and sealing the casing
- Cementing of the bottom of the Well
- A pressure test after the cement dries to make sure no water entry to the Well
LOT 2: Drilling a new borehole (section 3);
The new cased borehole will be used to house a seismic instrument, which is a highly-
sensitive vibration-measuring device. The borehole needs to be nearly vertical and
permanently sealed against water leakage from bottom to top. For this reason, the casing
must be completely coupled over its entire length to the surrounding rock by careful
cementation. A range of the inner diameter of the cased borehole is given to allow the
Contractor to use the most cost-efficient drill bit available for drilling the borehole. This
range also allows a variety of installations of seismic equipment in order to fit the site.
Technical specifications of the borehole are given in section.1 3 in these TOR; however,
some important aspects of the borehole would be:
- Corrosion-resistant stainless-steel casing
- Steel casing is cemented into the borehole to stabilize the casing, provide good coupling to
the ground, and maintain the integrity of underground aquifers.
- A cement/bentonite-based grouting between borehole and the casing to seal the borehole to
prevent any fluid movement, reinforce the hole against pressure.

Steps to rehabilitating the existing borehole include;
- Cleaning the borehole by pumping water and mud if exists
This step is important for following steps.
- Inspect the borehole and casing with camera
Inspecting the borehole with a camera is important to understand the status of the borehole

- Cleaning and sealing the casing
The casing shall be scraped, brushed, and emptied of all fluids and loose solids.
- Cementing of the bottom of the Well
In order to stop water entry from the bottom of the Well, shall be cemented with high-early
strength cement (Portland type III).
- Borehole leak test:
All tools and equipment required for successful completion of the test, including but not
limited to, air compressors, valves, air pressure gauges and fittings, are to be provided by
the contractor.
1. Wait 24 hours to allow cement and sealant to cure completely.
2. Fill the borehole to the top with water.
3. Seal the top of the borehole and pressurize the top air pocket to a minimum of 1,304 kPa
(150 psi).
4. Leave the borehole pressurized for 24 hours.
5. Check and record the pressure after 24 hours.
a. If the pressure has not dropped, proceed to step 7.
b. If the pressure has dropped (to account for water and pipe temperature stabilization),
bring the pressure back up to 1,304 kPa (150 psi) and leave the borehole for another 24
hours.
6. Check and record the pressure after an additional 24 hours. There should be no drop in
pressure after 48 hours.
7. Drain the water from the borehole and ensure that it is dry and clear of debris.

3.3.2 Drilling
The borehole will be drilled using an appropriately sized drill bit for the final choice of casing
diameters, while allowing for sufficient annular space to securely grout the casing to the rock
formation. It is recommended that the borehole be drilled between 21.6 cm (8.5 inches) and
26.7 cm (10-5/8 inches). Drilling should be done by the most cost-efficient method, which is
usually with a tri-cone rotary drill bit. Samples of drill cuttings (normal rock detritus created by
the rotary drilling and floated to the surface in drilling mud), should be collected at about 5-
meter intervals for each borehole for use in the description of the geological make-up within
each borehole. This information will be required as part of the drilling report.
The vertical offset or drift for the deep borehole shall not exceed 2.5 degrees from true vertical
measurement at any point from the top to the bottom of the cased hole. It is suggested that this
be achieved as follows: While drilling, pull-down pressure on the Kelly should be avoided. Drill
pressure should be provided solely by the weight of the drill collars. An appropriate device,
such as a Baker Tool TOTCO Recorder shall be used during the drilling to ensure that the hole
is not drifting from vertical.
When total depth of the borehole is reached at the proper diameter, circulation shall be
maintained for approximately one (1) hour to assure that the hole is free of cuttings and cavings.

must be round, straight, free of irregularities and seamless (cast, with no rolled seams). The

3.3.4 Cementation and grouting
The Contractor has the flexibility of selecting a preferred cementation method that will
completely bond the casing string to the rock walls over its entire depth with no voids or
shrinkage. For example, cementation can be accomplished through the casing using a cement
shoe and plunger method, cementation can be done via external grout tubes in the annulus
between the casing and host rock where the casing string is sealed by a welded plate at the
bottom. However, the preferred cementation process is to pump cement grout through the
interior of the casing using a plunger and cement shoe and flush the full volume up the annular
space between the exterior casing wall and the rock to the surface. The cement shoe and collar

cement, sand, bentonite (clay), water, and an expansive additive to prevent shrinkage upon
drying.
The borehole shall be cemented from bottom to top. The following procedure is recommended.
Cement slurry with sufficient volume to fill the annulus with at least 25% excess shall be
pumped into the casing. Then a latch down plug shall be inserted into the casing and washed
down with clear water. When the plug reaches the baffle, normally 1,000 pounds per square
inch of pressure should force the latching nose of the plug into the baffle and lock it in place.
Once the plug is seated, all pressure must be released to check for zero back-flow, this will
prove that the one-way valves are holding. When zero back-flow is obtained, the cement slurry
shall be allowed to cure for 24 hours under no pressure before performing any activities that
could disturb the bond, such as blowing or bailing the borehole dry of water or proceeding with
the acceptance tests.
After 24 hours, the casing shall be scraped, brushed, and emptied of all fluids and loose solids.
If the cement level drops in the annular space between the pipe and the hole, additional cement
slurry may be added around the casing directly from the surface. The level of the cement grout
in the annular space between the casing and the rock wall must be monitored during the
hardening process. If the level drops, additional cement grout must be added around the casing
from the top using small feed pipes if necessary.
